tn.text: Yahweh continues speaking to Ezekiel. All instances of "the city" refer to the "city" that Ezekiel carved onto the brick ([[:en:bible:notes:ezk:04:01|4:1]]).

"son of a human being" or "son of humanity." God calls Ezekiel this to emphasize that Ezekiel is only a human being. God is powerful and lives forever, but people are not. Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:02:01|2:3]]. AT: "mortal person" or "human"
"blade for cutting hair"

tn.ref: pass the razor over your head and your beard
tn.text: "shave your head and your face" or "remove the hair from your head and the beard from your face"
"Burn a third of your hair" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_fraction]])
middle

tn.ref: when the days of the siege are completed
tn.text: "when the days of Jerusalem's siege have ended" or "when the days have ended that you show how Jerusalem will put under siege"

tn.ref: take a third of the hair
tn.text: "take one of the three piles of hair" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_fraction]])

tn.ref: and strike it with the sword all around the city
tn.text: "and hit it with your sword all over the city"

tn.ref: scatter a third of it to the wind
tn.text: "let the wind blow the last third of your hair in different directions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_fraction]])

tn.ref: I will draw out a sword to chase after the people
tn.text: The word "sword" is a metonym for enemy soldiers who will attack with their swords, and to "draw out a sword" is to send the soldiers into battle. AT: "I will cause their enemies to pursue them and attack them with swords." (UDB) (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I will draw out a sword
tn.text: "I will pull a sword out of its container"
Yahweh continues to speak to Ezekiel.

Ezekiel was to do this when he shaved his hair and beard ([[:en:bible:notes:ezk:05:01|5:1]]) and before he burned the hair ([[:en:bible:notes:ezk:05:01|5:2]]). You may need to place these verses before those verses. "But when you shave off your hair and beard, and before you burn them, take ... After you have scattered the hair to the wind, then take" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_events]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_versebridge]])

tn.ref: a small number of hairs from them
tn.text: "a few hairs from the piles"

The word "them" refers to the hairs. Possible meanings are 1) the hairs were long enough so Ezekiel could tie them or 2) Ezekiel was to sew the hairs or otherwise attach them 3) Ezekiel was to place the hairs loosely in a fold of the garment.
Possible meanings are 1) "the cloth on your arms" ("your sleeves") (UDB) or 2) "the end of the cloth on your robe" ("your hem") or 3) the fold in the garment where it is tucked into the belt.

tn.ref: from there a fire will go out to all the house of Israel
tn.text: "from there a fire will spread out and burn up all the people of Israel." Yahweh speaks of how he will punish Israel as if he were going to set fire to a house and of the people of Israel as if they were the family that lives in that house but were at that time outside the house. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, in this case the Israelites, the descendants of Jacob over many years. AT: "the Israelite people group" Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:03:01|3:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Yahweh continues to speak.
Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:02:04|2:4]].
"This carving represents Jerusalem" ([[:en:bible:notes:ezk:04:01|4:1]])

tn.ref: in the midst of the nations
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) other nations were on all sides of Jerusalem or 2) "more important than all other nations."
Jerusalem is referred to as "her" and "she." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"the neighboring countries" or "the countries around her"

tn.ref: The people have rejected my judgments
tn.text: "The people of Israel and Jerusalem have refused to obey my judgments."
Yahweh continues to speak to the people of Israel and Judah.
Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:02:04|2:4]].

tn.ref: Because you are more troublesome than
tn.text: "because your sinfulness is worse than" or "because you are more unruly than"
"that are all around you."

tn.ref: have not walked in my statutes
tn.text: Walking is a metaphor for the way a person lives. AT: "have not lived according to my statutes" or "have not obeyed my statutes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: or acted according to my decrees
tn.text: "or obeyed my decrees"
"Look!" or "Listen!" or "Pay attention to what I am about to tell you!"

tn.ref: I will execute judgments within your midst
tn.text: "I will judge you in various ways" or "I will punish you" (UDB).
Yahweh continues speaking to the people of Israel and Jerusalem.

tn.ref: what I have not done and the like of which I will not do again
tn.text: "as I have not done before and will not do in a similar way again" or "like I have never done before and will never do again" (UDB).

tn.ref: because of all your disgusting actions
tn.text: "because of all the disgusting things you do." God was angry because the people were worshiping idols and false gods.

tn.ref: fathers will eat the children in your midst, and sons will eat their fathers
tn.text: Ezekiel is probably telling what will really happen when the people have no food.

tn.ref: I will execute judgment on you
tn.text: "I will judge you" or "I will punish you severely" (UDB)

tn.ref: and scatter to every direction all of you who are left
tn.text: "and I will force all of you who are left to go to different places."
Yahweh continues to speak to the people of Israel and Judah.

tn.ref: live—this is the Lord Yahweh's declaration—it
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Yahweh is speaking of himself as if he were another person AT: "live—I, the Lord Yahweh, am making this declaration—it" or 2) Ezekiel reminds his readers that he is quoting Yahweh AT: "live'—this is the Lord Yahweh's declaration—'it"
"as surely as I live." or "as true as it is that I am alive, it is also true that"
Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:02:04|2:4]].
ruined the place that Yahweh had set aside to be only for his use

"with all of those things of yours that I hate." You may need to make explicit that this refers to idols: "with all your idols, which I hate" or "with all your disgusting idols" (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: and with all your disgusting deeds
tn.text: "and with all the disgusting things that you do"

tn.ref: my eye will not have pity on you
tn.text: The word "eye" is a metonym for Yahweh. AT: "I will not have pity on you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"I will surely punish you"

tn.ref: they will be consumed by famine in your midst
tn.text: "many of them will die because of famine"
Yahweh continues to speak to the people of Israel and Judah.
"I will no longer be angry because I will have done everything I wanted to do because I was angry"

tn.ref: I will cause my fury toward them to rest
tn.text: The word "fury" means violent anger, and here it refers to punishment. "I will stop punishing them because I will have punished them fully." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"I will be satisfied that I have punished them enough"

tn.ref: when I have completed my fury against them
tn.text: "when I have finished punishing them"
Yahweh continues to speak to the people of Israel and Judah.
The words "wrath" and "fury" mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of wrath. AT: "because I will be very angry with you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"intense famine"

A "staff" was something that people leaned upon to support them. This phrase is a metaphor which means "remove the supply of food that you are depending upon." AT: "cut off your food supply" (UDB). See how "staff of bread" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:04:16|4:16]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Plague and blood will pass through you
tn.text: "Plague and violent death will pass through you." This violent death would be caused by war. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
